, appreciating the Yen rapidly. The result:

title: The Fed Holds Back, Apple Loses Steam, OpenAI Stirs Controversy – Where Are Smart Investors Moving Now?

children.text: As giants stumble in the game of influence and interests, are you ready to move toward a smarter, more agile investment ecosystem?
1. The Fed – Neither Injecting Nor Withdrawing Liquidity
Markets were shaken by rumors that the Fed was injecting $20B into the system. In truth, the Fed merely
no new money, no QE – just a pause in tightening (QT).
The market needs real support – but it won’t come from central banks this time.
2. Apple & OpenAI – Giants Caught in Their Own Traps
Apple – From Market Gatekeeper to Defendant in Its Own Ecosystem
Apple has long required all developers to use its in-app payment system.
It charges a 30% fee per transaction – often referred to as the “Apple Tax.”
Epic resisted, launched its own payment system, got banned from the App Store – and sued Apple.
The court ruled: Apple must allow developers to place external payment links.
Revenue from services (App Store, Apple Music, iCloud…) is Apple’s fastest-growing segment.
Losing control over this revenue stream threatens:
When a revenue model based on tight control is challenged by law, even a brand as dominant as Apple becomes vulnerable.
OpenAI – When Nonprofit Ideals Clash with Billion-Dollar Ambitions
OpenAI was founded as a nonprofit organization, with a mission to benefit humanity through AI – co-founded by Elon Musk.
But after ChatGPT’s success, the organization:
Sought to sell $40B in equity at a $150B valuation
Promised “capped returns” (100x) to skirt nonprofit restrictions
A nonprofit “selling out” to a profit-driven arm is seen as a strategic loophole to commercialize public-interest AI.
Elon Musk has publicly sued OpenAI, alleging betrayal of its original mission.
If governments, communities, or investors react strongly, OpenAI’s valuation and funding prospects could collapse due to a loss of trust.
“Big names are no longer safe havens. When profit motives clash with ethics, risk is always near.”
In today’s world, nothing is too big to fail – not even Apple or OpenAI.
Valuations – whether stocks, tokens, or equity – must rest on sustainable, transparent, and ethical foundations.
3. Gold, Oil, and Global Geopolitical Unrest
Gold surged 3.5% over two consecutive days
, driven by Chinese buyers flooding the market post-holiday.
, fueled by hopes of a ceasefire in the Red Sea – while India and Pakistan reignited tensions in Kashmir.
Capital is fleeing to perceived “safe havens” – but
physical gold alone is too slow, too rigid
4. Trade Wars: From the US and China to Canada and Vietnam
Trump continued attacking China and Canada, while
Vietnam is reportedly among the first 6 countries to enter trade talks with the US.
Trade wars are no longer about tariffs – they’re about structural control of global economic power.
So, where should investors turn amid rising volatility?

title: When the Market Shook – The Elites Already Knew and Quietly Grew Rich

After the COVID-19 pandemic, central banks—especially the U.S. Federal Reserve (FED)—took extreme actions:
Printed massive amounts of money to save the economy
Kept interest rates near 0% for over two years
Global inflation exploded—especially in the U.S., where CPI soared past 7%, the highest in 40 years.
The FED raised rates at a record pace: from 0% to 5% in just 18 months
U.S. stocks plunged 20–30%, real estate froze, gold and crypto tumbled
Countless companies went bankrupt, banks were flooded with bad debt, small investors were wiped out

title: [Expert Insight] Tariffs Through the Investor’s Lens: Opportunities Behind the Uncertainty

children.text: Trump, Tariffs, and Diverging Reactions from Different Types of Investors
The question “What do you think about Trump’s tariffs?” may seem simple, but for investors, it carries significant weight — because
From my personal perspective and data-driven analysis, here’s what I believe:
– Tariffs reduce corporate profits, directly affecting EPS (earnings per share) and overall market outlook.
– Trade tensions dampen investor sentiment, often triggering widespread sell-offs.
– Tariffs increase construction material costs, potentially delaying projects.
– Economic uncertainty discourages capital inflows into real estate, increasing speculative risks.
Fed and central banks may need to inject liquidity to support growth
– Unlike traditional crises, tariffs allow for monetary easing
— because higher prices are policy-driven, not demand-driven.
Bitcoin — with its decentralized nature and limited supply — increasingly resembles gold
, with added benefits of liquidity and cross-border transferability.
Tariffs = More Liquidity, Less Inflation: A Fascinating Paradox
Normally, printing money leads to inflation. But under a tariff-driven scenario:
Import prices rise due to policy → “imported inflation”
Domestic consumption doesn’t surge → no wage-price spiral
reason to ease monetary policy without “breaking the rules”
: Increased liquidity, stable inflation, and a favorable environment for digital asset investors.
Bitcoin: From Rebel Asset to “Digital Gold”
Bitcoin was once considered too volatile to be a safe haven. But in today’s climate:
Trust in the traditional financial system is waning
Capital is flowing into decentralized, transparent stores of value
Bitcoin is increasingly seen as “digital gold” — with rising defensive appeal
Conclusion: Where Are the Real Opportunities?
While most investors fear macroeconomic policy changes, a more informed minority is
moving early to ride the wave
Tariffs are no longer just a trade conflict tool — they’re
a catalyst for the rise of non-traditional assets
“Don’t fear market corrections caused by policy — understand how capital moves beneath the surface.”

title: [Weekly Insight] Opportunity Amid Crisis: When T.U.N.A. Becomes the New Map for Investors

children.text: In a week full of volatility, BeQ Holdings presents a strategic market insight – both systematic and grounded in reality – to help investors better understand the evolving landscape of global finance.

We are, in fact, witnessing a
, where the global financial order is being reshaped. In this context, the
– offers the most accurate lens for understanding today’s market.
Asset prices are extremely volatile. Not only are stocks unstable, but even gold – traditionally a safe haven – is struggling to hold ground.
Policies from global powers shift by the day. A single tweet from the White House or a statement from Beijing can trigger massive capital flows.
The link between cause and effect is becoming increasingly detached. Good news doesn’t always drive the market up – and bad news may, paradoxically, spark a rally.
Clear lines between right and wrong are disappearing. For investors without a system, markets become dangerously unpredictable.

Central banks are accelerating money printing to support domestic economies.

title: Global Stock Market Trends: US Declines, Europe Surges

children.text: 1. Overview of the Stock Market at the Beginning of the Year
The chart below illustrates the changes in global stock indices, including:
: Represents global markets excluding the US.
The data is standardized from the beginning of the year, allowing investors to easily track performance over time.
a. US Stock Market (MSCI USA) Declines Sharply
After stabilizing early in the year, the MSCI USA index began to drop significantly from February, hitting its lowest point in mid-March.
This decline may reflect investor concerns about economic policies and the investment environment in the US.
In contrast to the US market, the MSCI Europe index surged after January, reaching a peak above 115 by mid-March.
The recovery of the European market suggests that capital is shifting away from the US to more promising regions.
c. Global Market (MSCI World ex USA) Remains Stable but Uneven
The MSCI World ex USA index showed growth but at a lower rate than MSCI Europe.
This indicates market divergence, with Europe emerging as the strongest performer.
: Changes in tax, trade, and investment policies have negatively impacted market confidence.
: Investors tend to seek opportunities in Europe and other markets outside the US.
: Supportive policies have contributed to the strong performance of European stocks.
4. Investment Strategies for the Upcoming Period
Investors should consider increasing exposure to the European market
, where strong recovery signals are evident.
Be cautious with the US market
, especially amid ongoing political and economic uncertainties.
, focusing on regions with stable policies and strong growth potential.

title: In-depth Analysis of Goldman Sachs’ Gold Demand Chart

children.text: This chart reflects the trend in gold demand among central banks and financial institutions on the London OTC market amid global economic and geopolitical fluctuations. Let’s analyze it in more depth through the following aspects:
Before 2022, the average demand was relatively low (~17 tonnes).
After the freezing of the Russian Central Bank’s assets in 2022, gold demand surged dramatically.
From 2023 to 2024, gold purchases showed strong fluctuations but remained at high levels.
The forecast for 2025 indicates that demand is likely to continue rising, reaching 205 tonnes (117 tonnes excluding U.S. exports).
This surge suggests that gold is becoming a more significant reserve asset for central banks and financial institutions, especially during uncertain times.
2. Impact of the Russian Central Bank Asset Freeze (2022)
Following the freezing of Russian assets, gold demand skyrocketed.
This reflects a significant shift in how nations and financial institutions approach foreign exchange reserves.
Central banks may have increased gold purchases to:
Reduce reliance on the U.S. dollar
and assets that can be frozen in geopolitical conflicts.
Protect the value of foreign exchange reserves
Buying gold has become a defensive strategy against sanctions and political instability.
3. The Role of the U.S. in Gold Transactions
A key factor affecting the data is that
88 tonnes of gold were shipped from London to the U.S.
Concerns about potential U.S. tariffs on gold.
Goldman Sachs believes U.S. tariffs on gold are unlikely
since gold is primarily a financial asset rather than an industrial input.
If U.S. tariffs on gold were implemented, this could create instability in the gold market, prompting financial institutions to seek alternative reserve strategies.
4. Forecast for 2025 and Key Influencing Factors
205 tonnes of gold will be purchased in January 2025
leading central banks to increase gold reserves.
, with some countries shifting holdings from USD to gold.
S. Federal Reserve (Fed) interest rate policy:
If rates decrease, gold will become even more attractive.
If current conditions persist, gold demand could continue rising in 2025 and beyond.
5. Impact on the Gold Market and Global Finance
When central bank gold demand rises sharply, gold prices may continue to trend upwards.
If more countries shift part of their foreign reserves to gold, this could weaken the USD’s dominance.
Central banks, especially in emerging markets or those facing sanctions, may increase gold holdings instead of USD or U.S. Treasuries.
Gold is likely to become an even more crucial part of national foreign reserve strategies.
especially after the freezing of Russian assets in 2022.
Central banks are actively accumulating gold
to safeguard their reserves from political and economic risks.
The U.S. remains influential in the gold market,
but concerns about tariffs could affect trade flows.
2025 could be a strong growth year for gold,
driven by economic recession fears, geopolitical tensions, and Fed policies.
The financial market could be deeply affected,
from gold prices and USD valuation to national reserve strategies.
For more insights on the gold market and investment strategies, follow BEQ Holdings.
BEQ Holdings – A Leader in Financial Advisory and Investment.
